paragraphs.text: I'm developing 'The Arillian Farm brand' to see if I can entice folks to spend a minute or two in our little nook of the web, watch a video or read a thing, then maybe chuckle or smile and throw a couple bucks our way if they enjoyed something. To that end, I've been working on this website for a few days now and I’ve been poking around the internet, checking out sites from authors who have content on the web (do people still say web?)

Everyone seems to have a blog, but I don’t actually believe that people read blogs in this day and age (do people even say day and age still? … is it day and age or day in age?), but even if this blog post goes unread, the more links and content my site has, the better SEO it will have… right? Now I think I’m going to put a task on my Kanban Board to read more about SEO... and about making blog entries that people might want to read.

When I decided (a few weeks ago) to make this site and start putting the Arillian Farm brand out there, I wanted to make (find a free template for) a Kanban board for myself like the one I used to use when someone else was paying me to write software. Instead of moving tasks across columns though, I decided to use Sheet's built-in 'sort' function and I just have a list-selectable status and I generally keep my Sheet sorted by Status (unless there is some other metric I want to look at such as started date or priority) As soon as I started throwing tasks on my Sheet... OMG it felt so good!

Having a place to jot down the millions of things I want to do in my life and break them down into smaller tasks is like lifting thoughts out of my brain and putting them into a Pensive from Harry Potter! Being able to sort and search my dreams and accomplishments from my phone and my laptop is luxury! And oh hot damn the sweet sweet dopamine release when I change the status of a task to finished is almost better than a puff of weed! I've missed Kanbaning. Doing things and keeping track of them, so simple, but so satisfying.
4:00AM Out into The Dark Hotness. First task: Grab Basil For Our Chickens' and Okra For Our Dogs' Breakfasts.

sections.text: 4:30AM Barnyard Breakfast! (I feed our chickens before sunrise for two reasons 1- I want them to lay early in the day because nesting in the midday heat is stressful for their bodies. (2) After sunrise a flock of pigeons and doves show up to pick through any leftovers.

5:00AM DOoooUGH - I’m going to make sourdough bread later in the day, so I need to 'wake up' the starter (remove it from fridge and let come to room temp). It needs to be “fed” a half cup of flour and a half cup of water once a week and if I’m not going to be using it that day.

6:00AM Coffee break (my friend Christa got me this amazing mug) I’ve been making cold brew instead of hot coffee … partly ‘cause its hot and partly because its less acidic than hot coffee. I put it in my fridge door ‘cause I think the constant agitation form the door opening and closing will help it brew… but that could be fake news.

6:30AM Dog breakfast and shift change! Our two male dogs can’t be together anymore (due to Huey stalking and wanting to kill Pajama), so we keep them separated by a locked door –or leashed to opposing walls at all times. I swap who’s in the bedroom and who’s outside after breakfast so they both have a chance to play with Xena and play fetch outside before its too hot.
Weeding and Chicken treating

TENDING WATER GARDEN… THE OVERFLOW POND WATER FLOWS INTO THE CHICKENS COOP, SO THEY GET ANOTHER MUDDY / WET AREA TO COOL OFF (originally I was going to have the pond extend under their fence, but it turns out I’m not great at spacial analysis and my pond tarp was no where near large enough for that
Make poo piles ... clean the chicken coop and goat bedding (for later use in soil)

7:45AM On Tuesdays we break our weekend fast with a fresh smoothie that Arthur has designed to deliver the maximum nutritional value with the least amount of calories and a somewhat palatable taste. (I’ve tried to recreate the smoothies myself and they are definitely not palatable)
8:30AM Arthur is off to work. Time to start fleshing out this blog entry
10:30AM Start making dough for sourdough bread
11:30AM Final Fantasy Break while the bread proofs
12:00PM Ice the livestock and give the chickens some frozen corn treats
12:30 Continue with bread and Formatting this blog entry

2:00 feed the chickens and goats their afternoon meal – the goats get a little bit of chicken food because they scream at me for all the world to hear if I feed the chickens but not them. And the chickens don’t get oatmeal or banana in the afternoon ‘cause apparently 2 bananas is where I draw the line on over-treating my chickens. THey do get the egg shells from our morning smoothie though (to help them get enough ‘grit’ for digestion).
2:15 feed the dogs their afternoon meal
2:30 Bake the bread and continue working on Arillian Farm site
3:00 Tea Time / back to working on the site while I watch some nostalgic 90s comfort tv (currently half way through season 1 of Who’s The Boss)
5:00 Coop up the chickens, collect the eggs, and tether the dogs
5:30 Arthur comes home, relax until bedtime
8:00 zzz

data.entry_subject: From Bread winner to bread baker

feature_section_1.caption: OR From bringing home the bacon to stay at home farmer

paragraphs.text: In 2016 I completed a four month coding bootcamp in Silicone Valley and was relieved and surprised to land a job two weeks after I got home.
At first, I loved my new career. It was more engaging and challenging than any job I'd had before and I was part of a fun, young software team.

At the height of my seven years with the company, there were five developers. We had a shared kanban board. There were pot lucks and team building events and we had this thing we did where one of us would go 'doobee doobee doop doop doop' and the rest of us would all go 'ahhhhaa' like in that one Annie Lennox song. It was just a great feeling of teamness. Plus, with my new salary and renalt income from my investment property, I was the bigger breadwinner of the Arillian household.
About four years in, my company started having layoffs. Eventually our team got reduced to two and my least favorite co-worker became my boss.

A few weeks after the final round of layoffs, we closed our physical office and started working from home. My new boss immediately hired three developers to work remotely from other countries (two from Ukraine and one from Nicaragua). We all worked at very different times of day, which made communication slow and difficult.

It didn't help that our boss had assigned us overlapping tasks in the same couple of files and then stopped responding to work chat and emails. For weeks, we struggled with immense issues merging our work together and our codebase kept getting more and more buggy, so I started waking up at 1:00 or 2:00 AM to try to communicate with the Ukrainian developers before they 'pushed' their final file changes for the day.
Eventually the Ukrainian developers dropped off the project and I was suddenly thrust into the role of de facto project manager/ lead developer without an actual raise or title change.

I felt like I was a ghost of myself. I stopped doing things I love, like cooking, gardening or playing with the dogs and all I did was work. I suddenly had to learn to manage the entire infrastructure supporting our application as well as sorting out the buggy code itself and my laptop was always there, tethered to my brain.

The only thing that made it bearable was that I started working my closely with my coworker in Nicaragua. He's hardworking and communicative and he knows more about certain aspects of computer science than I and vice versus, so we worked well together in that regard,
But mainly, I felt like I had someone on my team at work again.

We would message on the work chat about what was going on in our lives and when I told him I have chickens, he sent me a feather with a picture of Nicaragua painted on it… which is one of the most thoughtful unique things I’ve received.

We had work and gardening in common, but his life was very different than mine. He's married with three kids whom he always spoke pridefully of and he seemed to go to great lengths to take care of them. He lost his mother during COVID and after that, since he wasn’t able to get vaccines in Nicaragua for his family, he drove them (on dirt roads through small towns etc… not on a highway or anything) to Honduras to get vaccinated. He’s just a very kind and thoughtful person.

So, when the owner of my company, who had never actually evaluated the work of my coworker, asked me to fire him because he wanted to put a different remote developer on our team, I decided to quit and leave my coworker the job security of being the only employee with any knowledge of our project thus far.
Well, that makes it sound more dramatic and altruistic than it actually was. I didn’t decide to quit on the spot when they told me I was going to have to fire my co-worker.

I'd been training for it, easing up on my Uber Eats and Amazon Habits for months and tracking my spending on a Google Sheet in anticipation of completion of my second rental home (on the same property, behind my first rental house) near ASU.

I was managing to keep my expenses within my new projected rental income and Arthur received a promotion from his company, so the universe seemed to be saying, it was fine for me to quit, take a breath and re-asses what I actually wanted to do with my life.

At the next zoom meeting, after the owner asked me to fire my coworker,  I gave three months notice (so I could train my replacement). They kept my coworker on, and I've been gardening, cooking, hanging with my critters, writing and coding the day away on my own terms ever since.

feature_section_1.caption: 1 - Stand Mixer, 2 - Electric Miter Saw, 3 - Silicone Muffin Wrappers, 4 - Matrix Drill + Attachments (Black&Decker), 5 - Wet Tile Saw, 6 - Air Fryer, 7 - Construction Bags, 8 - Painting Edger, 9 - Air Compressor + attachments, 10 - Sharpal

paragraphs.text: 1- Stand Mixer

Google's AI, Gemini, reckons my Kitchen Aid stand mixer was made in the 1950s or '60s. It was a gift from my ex fiance like 15 years ago, but she's still kicking (so much so that I have to hold the bowl in place sometimes)! Whipping cream and kneading bread are so much easier with a stand mixer than by hand (or with a hand mixer) and its great for mixing simpler stuff like pancake batter or cookie dough.
2- Electric Miter Saw

I can't imagine hand sawing anything anymore. We have a Hitachi Compound 10inch miter saw. (I bought it off Amazon about seven or eight years ago.) The arm pivots, so you can cut angles across the end of a board to make nice wood frames. It takes two cuts to cut a 2x6inch board when it's flat thought, so if I would change anything about it I would get a 12inch blade instead of 10inches
3- Silicone Muffin Tins
I use these for everything, holding hardware or beads, epoxy molds, sauce cups and obviously baking. First bought some of these off Amazon about ten years ago. (There's no brand information on them).
4- Black&Decker Cordless Matrix Drill + Attachments

There is a 'standard drill head', a 'hammer head' and 'an impact drill' as well as a small jigsaw and circular saw (that will cut through thin wood like fence boards or finishing wood). (We also used to have a sander attachment, but I accidentally ripped the velcro for the sandpaper off of it... oops). I use this drill at least once a week for something or another. (I might use it less if I didn't have goats trying to break everything around them all the time). (I bought my drill at Home Depot tweleve years ago, but I believe this drill can only be ordered online now)
5 - Wet Tile Saw
I've tiled a fair amount of walls and floors in the last three or four yeas and this $20.00 tile saw from Harbor Freight just keeps on truckin'!
6 - Air Fryer

I use our air frier to cook almost everything I eat lately. Things come out crisp (unlike in a microwave), but its faster than an oven and causes much less heat in the kitchen (which is super nice when you're struggling just to keep it 85F inside during the summer). Arthur bought our air frier off of Amazon earlier this year. The brand is Dreo, but not sure the model number... it's big enough to bake a pie in, which is cool)
7 - Construction Bags

Between our house in Mesa and my rental property in Tempe, I do a decent amount of landscaping and gardening every week. The bag is rigid enough so you can fold it over to keep it open while you fill it and it's great for hauling leaves, soil, and tools. I like that I can fit the straps over my shoulders to make carrying heavy things easier. Plus, I feel like it's a pretty good lower body and core workout to fill, lift and cary a bag of soil or mulch across the yard. (I bought a 4-pack of: 'DURASACK Heavy Duty Storage Tote Bags 22-Gallon Rugged Woven Polypropylene Moving Bag, Holds up to 500 Pounds' off Amazon about 2 years ago and they're holding up great)
8 - Painting Edger

The reason why I love painting edgers is because I hate dealing with blue tape... I always rip it jagged. I always forget to use a razor and peel paint off of the wall when I go to remove the tape and it makes every job take at least twice as long when you have to go around and tape all the edges. Edgers eliminate that, so I like them.
9 - Air Compressor + attachments

Air compressors are great 'cause they can fill your pool rafts or car tires and also provide the force needed to drive finishing nails into wooden trim or staple livestock fencing or chicken wire to fence posts. (I bought our Bostitch air compressor (with two nail guns and a staple gun attachment) off Amazon about five or six years ago and its keeps performing like a champion).
10 - Sharpal Multi-sharpener
I use this to keep my gardening tools sharp (lawn mower blades, hedge trimmers, construction scissors etc). It keeps everything cutting sharp and cleanly. (I bought ours on Amazon about a year ago).

data.entry_subject: Caring For Chickens in the Summer

feature_section_1.caption: Unfortunately summers in AZ can be too much for chickens. Here's what I've gleaned from my experiences over the years.

paragraphs.text: What Not To Do:

I'm sad and ashamed to say I've lost chickens to the desert heat. My initial mistake was that I ran an air conditioner and kept the barn fully closed in the summer (with an insulated doggy door for the goats and a small portal cut out for the chickens to go outside) and that was fine... until Totes (or McGoats) kicked the doggy door off and hot air was coming in faster than the AC could cool the room (right next to our hen's preferred laying spot at the time). It was 120F out and four chickens each laid an egg and died one on top of the other. I made some major changes after that.

I've since read that air conditioning your hens can prevent them from appropriately climatizing, so when there's an act of Goat or some other inevitability, they overheat way too easily. (I've also read, for similar reasons, you should not use a heater in winter for chickens unless it actually freezes where you are)
I have a much more hands-on system that's been going better:
Ice Ice baby, ba-gawk

I made an 'ice house' for my chickens in a shaded area of their outdoor habitat. (I call it an ice house because I put a gallon of ice in once or twice a day --depending on if its going to be over 110 or not). My chickens also have access to three large buckets of water all day in the summer. Around 8-10AM and at 2:00-4:00PM every day, I put a quart of ice in each bucket (this is about the maximum amount of ice our freezer can stand to make in the summer. Not only do ice containers take up a lot of space, they also make the freezer work really hard. We actually had to buy a new fridge/freezer this summer because our old one (was from the early 2000s) and could no longer get cold enough to freeze three gallons of water twice a day in our 85 degree house.
Wallowing in the Mud
I overflow the water buckets in the mornings so there is cool mud around the buckets for the chickens to wallow in. They also like to wrap themselves around the water buckets to stay cool.
Wading for relief
We also added a pond to the 'barnyard' (that is in the shade in the late afternoon), so now the chickens have somewhere to cool their heels (and peck at lily pads and mosquitofish).

feature_section_1.caption: I’ve been busting my ass setting up this site and combing through Google Photos for pictures and videos of our lil farm yard

paragraphs.text: Technically

In 2015 I completed a four-month full-stack developer ‘boot camp’ in Silicon Valley. At that moment in time, there was some debate about whether Google’s framework, Angular JS would remain the preferred framework for web apps or if Facebook’s React, would usurp Angular. My bootcamp taught us Angular for two months and React for one week… and then React blew up and is now the dominant framework of the modern web.

I, however, fell in love with good ol’ Angular JS in all it’s two-way binding glory. I can React a little, but I just like to get all up in the HTML files with my javascript. It just feels right to me!

Also, it only took me a couple weeks to make a serverless angular js site –that I am hosting for free on Github Pages… and Github Pages is easy to use… and free. So at least until I get a chance to see if I can actually drive traffic to our site, I’m just another white girl over here with no back end.

If I actually do generate interest in our site, I’ll probably convert it to React and set up a cloud server on AWS so I can use outside APIs to manage site assets more efficiently and possibly set up more interactive features.
Marketing

I’ve been busting my ass setting up this site and combing through our Google Photos for videos and pictures of our critters, in hopes of launching our YouTube channel with enough content to gain some traction by Black Friday (So I can maybe sell a couple of the cute holiday t-shirts I'm working on for our Zazzle store). I reckon we want our YouTube channel up before October if we want any sort of following by then.

I’ve got a solid backlog of content for future releases and dozens of tasks to work on my Arillian Farm Kanban, so I feel prepared to hit the ground running with weekly content releases for this site as well as our YouTube channel starting next Friday.
I'm releasing new content on Friday afternoons because I figure folks will be on their phones trying to get their weekend started by like 3:00PM on Friday. Plus, it tends to be payday.

With luck, our YouTube Channel may one day capitalize on our critters' adorableness and garner enough subscribers and views to generate ad revenue. In the meantime, I hope YouTube views will lead to Google searches and page views for this site. That alone would be cool because I feel like I have some things I can share with folks that’ll spread a little joy or at least give 'em something to noodle on. But also, I have lumber and gardening supply habits to support, so I’d be living the full dream if people liked my stuff enough to kick me a buck or two on Go Fund Me and/or buy a Totes McGoats Tote Bag or T-shirt from Zazzle.
Personally

Even if I don’t generate any income, I’m glad I built this site. Building up content has given me an opportunity to look back on some fond memories in our lil farm yard (and offload some videos from my almost-full Google Pictures account to Arillian Farm’s YouTube channel and pictures to Imagur).

Plus rummaging through js and html files again feels good on my brain and keyboard shorthands and javascript syntax came back to me surprisingly fast and if/when I need to stop LARPing as a farmer and go back into the real workforce, converting this site from Angular to React will be an excellent learning opportunity and my Github repository and the site itself will probably be good supplements to my resume.

data.entry_subject: Falling in love with Autumn in the desert!

paragraphs.text: Growing up in California, fall blew in with the gusty, dusty Santa Ana Winds and it brought the unfortunate end of summer vacation and return to school. I was not a fan. In California, I just wanted it to be summer all the time.

As an adult, living in the Arizona desert, I notice that the fall does come with increased traffic; folks around here say you can tell it’s fall when the license plates start to change color (from all the ‘snow birds’ returning to their winter homes from states with milder summers and more intense winters). But most importantly, fall means the end of the interminable summer heat.

By mid-August I’ve had enough lows in the 90s and highs in the 110 plus degree days, to make me question everything that made me decide to put down roots here. So when I start to see NFL jerseys and pumpkin spice lattes going on sale, a happy little hope starts building inside me.

As the endless burning summer heat gives way to cool mornings, festivals start to spring up, bars start to open their patios and life returns to my backyard gardens. They say Arizona doesn’t have seasons, but I love the not Summer that takes up the other half of the year.
Aug 20, 2024 - Started Clearing Garden Beds and Making Soil

All the metaphors about grass roots seem so much more apt now that I've tried to dig some actual grass roots out of the soil. They stretch deep, don't let go and come back strong with even a little encouragement.
Aug 28, 2024 - Planted First Round of Seedlings Indoors

Most of the seeds for Fall said to transplant 'after the soil has cooled', so I optimistically started them inside under a grow light (that Arthur designed for work a while back) with a 24 hour light cycle.
Aug 31, 2024 - First Sprouts Spring Up
Pumpkins, wheat and Peas were poking their heads up after about a week
Sept, 8, 2024 - More Sprouts and growth inside
Lettuce, Broccoli and spinach are sprouting and wheat is growing long and I planted some garlic outside
Sept 12, 2024 - Second Round Of Indoor Planting
More of the same seeds from round 1
Sept 19, 2024 - Taking It Outside

We had a 10 day forecast of all under 100 degree high temps, so I started planting seeds and some round 1 plants... but then we had a heat wave, so all of the peas and lettuce died and sparrows ate most of the broccoli, beet and kale seeds and sprouts
Sept 24, 2024 - Indoor plants are ready... but its too hot to plant outside now
It hit 110 for the next several days and it started to get hot in our grow room. A lot of sprouts died
Oct 2, 2024 - Still over 105 outside, but the indoor plants were starting to bloom and wither

I planted all the herbs I had started from cuttings on a semi-shaded hill at my house in Tempe and tried to find a suitable home for all the rest at my Mesa house and planted seeds between the indoor-started plants
Oct 7, 2024 - Finally getting cool morning temps
...but then of course there's the critters that want to eat everything
Oct 17, 2024 - We're under 100 for a high and it looks like we may pull off a lil crop after all
